citations.narrative:
In the back holding and isolation rooms housing dogs, the bottom metal grates within each enclosure have multiple areas
of peeling/flaking coating and rusted metal. The exposed metal is beginning to have small defects in the surface. Surfaces
in disrepair such as rusted and pitting metal cannot be adequately sanitized and may harbor organic matter or bacteria
that can cause illness or poor health in the dogs. Additionally, the actively flaking coating can be ingested by the dog’s
housed within the enclosure and lead to potential illness. Correct by ensuring that all surfaces that come into contact with
dogs or cats are free of rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation and protect the animals from illness.

A total of 14 kittens housed in 2 enclosures not being provided the minimum floor space as required by the Animal
Welfare Act. Each enclosure provides a total of approximately 1,518 sq. inches (10.5 sq. feet) of floor space. Each kitten
is required to have a minimum of 3 sq. feet of floor space. The enclosures each contain 7 kittens, requiring 21 sq. feet of
floor space. Failing to provide adequate space can cause discomfort, crowding, poor sanitation, increased incidence of
illness. Correct by ensuring that all cats are provided with the minimum space required by the Animal Welfare Act.

A total of 11 puppies housed in 4 enclosures are not being provided the minimum floor space as required by the Animal
Welfare Act. The enclosures measure approximately 24” x 60” and provide a total of 1,440 sq. inches of space.
- Three enclosures have three puppies each who require a total of 1,977 sq. inches, 1,712 sq. inches, and 1,681 sq.
inches of space respectively.
- A single enclosure has two puppies who require a total of 1,485 sq. inches of space.
Failing to provide adequate space can cause discomfort, crowding, poor sanitation, increased incidence of illness, and
lead to developmental abnormalities especially in larger breed dogs. Correct by ensuring that all dogs are provided with
the minimum space required by the Animal Welfare Act.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 26, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
